resources.description: Citation Information: nOriginator: nEarth Science & Observation Center (ESOC), CIRES, University of Colorado at Boulder nPublication Date:  2012 nTitle: nSurface Temperature Anomalies derived from Night Time ASTER and LANDSAT Data Corrected for Solar and Topographic Effects around Ouray, ColoradonEdition: nFirst nPublication Information: nPublication Place: nEarth Science & Observation Center, Cooperative Institute for Research in Environmental Science (CIRES), University of Colorado, Boulder nPublisher: nEarth Science &Observation Center (ESOC), CIRES, University of Colorado at Boulder nDescription: nThis map shows areas of anomalous surface temperature in Ouray identified from ASTER and LANDSAT thermal data and spatial based insolation model. The temperature for the ASTER data was calculated using the Emissivity Normalization Algorithm that separate temperature from emissivity. The incoming solar radiation was calculated using spatial based insolation model developed by Fu and Rich (1999). Then the temperature due to solar radiation was calculated using emissivity derived from ASTER data. The residual temperature, i.e. temperature due to solar radiation subtracted from ASTER temperature was used to identify thermally anomalous areas. nnAreas having anomalous temperature in the ASTER data are shown in blue diagonal hatch, while areas having anomalous temperature in the LANDSAT data are shown in magenta on the map. Thermal springs and areas with favorable geochemistry are also shown. Springs or wells having non-favorable geochemistry are shown as blue dots.n
resources.name: aster-landsatouray.pdf

title: Areas with Surface Thermal Anomalies as Detected by ASTER and LANDSAT Data in Ouray, Colorado
name: areas-with-surface-thermal-anomalies-as-detected-by-aster-and-landsat-data-in-ouray-colora
notes: Citation Information: nOriginator: nEarth Science & Observation Center (ESOC), CIRES, University of Colorado at Boulder nPublication Date:  2012 nTitle: nSurface Temperature Anomalies derived from Night Time ASTER and LANDSAT Data Corrected for Solar and Topographic Effects around Ouray, ColoradonEdition: nFirst nPublication Information: nPublication Place: nEarth Science & Observation Center, Cooperative Institute for Research in Environmental Science (CIRES), University of Colorado, Boulder nPublisher: nEarth Science &Observation Center (ESOC), CIRES, University of Colorado at Boulder nDescription: nThis map shows areas of anomalous surface temperature in Ouray identified from ASTER and LANDSAT thermal data and spatial based insolation model. The temperature for the ASTER data was calculated using the Emissivity Normalization Algorithm that separate temperature from emissivity. The incoming solar radiation was calculated using spatial based insolation model developed by Fu and Rich (1999). Then the temperature due to solar radiation was calculated using emissivity derived from ASTER data. The residual temperature, i.e. temperature due to solar radiation subtracted from ASTER temperature was used to identify thermally anomalous areas. nnAreas having anomalous temperature in the ASTER data are shown in blue diagonal hatch, while areas having anomalous temperature in the LANDSAT data are shown in magenta on the map. Thermal springs and areas with favorable geochemistry are also shown. Springs or wells having non-favorable geochemistry are shown as blue dots.n
